description:
Molossus alvarezi, also known as Alvarez's mastiff bat, is a species of free-tailed bat found in Central America. It belongs to the genus Molossus, which is part of the family Molossidae, commonly known as mastiff bats.

Molossus alvarezi is a small- to medium-sized bat, with a body length typically ranging from 80 to 100 millimeters (3.1 to 3.9 inches) and a wingspan of approximately 300 to 350 millimeters (11.8 to 13.8 inches). The species is characterized by its broad, rounded ears and its black or dark brown fur, which can have a slight glossy or iridescent appearance.

These bats are primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of flying insects, such as moths, beetles, and flies. They are known to roost in caves, abandoned buildings, and other sheltered locations, often forming large colonies.

The geographical distribution of Molossus alvarezi is limited to parts of Central America, including Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua. The species is listed as Least Concern on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List, as it is widely distributed and not currently facing significant threats.
